title: Why does pop music suck so much? - Quora

response.answer_text: Modern pop music sucks because of the digital innovation, which came into place in the mid-1980’s. Before digital, there was the understanding that the music business was run by musicians, and those musicians were expected to concertize, and to be able to playback their hits live, using real instruments. The advent of digital means that any person, even those lacking all musical talent and ability, can now create music that is automated by computers, essentially. Digital wizardry allows anyone to make something that roughly “sounds like music”. Even a live performance can be totally, or partially, pre-programmed with synthesis. The MTV ethos also damaged the industry; prior to MTV, fans rarely cared too much what a musical act looked like. In fact, many, if not most, pop musicians were physically plain… But that was okay because it was their music that mattered. The radio was the prime medium of pop music, and in that environment, how a musician looked was of little or no consequence. Paul Simon has recently said that, were he and Art Garfunkel to be starting out today, they likely would not meet with success, because they were not especially handsome or dramatic-looking and did not dance. The MTV ethos convinced fans that the visual element of a pop act was as important— if not more important—- than the music being made. In the 1960’s, there were not a whole lot of supermodel-looking music acts, and when they DID crop up (like Jackie deShannon, Bobbie Gentry, Nancy Sinatra, Michelle Phillips, Grace Slick or Gayle McCormick) they were not automatically fawned over because they were beautiful, and you’d better believe that audiences demanded that they prove themselves as powerful musicians first and foremost (which these six women did). Nowadays, with the world of synthesis and digital wizardry, a female popstar need not prove that she is a musical talent… because all her shortcomings can be easily fixed by digital technology. But she had better be hawt-looking, and I mean, all over. (And even her appearance can be tweaked endlessly on computers). The other thing that has damaged pop music is the Star Search/American Idol/Britain’s Got Talent ethos. In the 1960’s and 1970’s, there was the feeling that music was best left up to the professionals… namely, musicians who could really sing and play. Starting in the 1980’s, with TV shows like STAR SEARCH, et.al., suddenly music became a competition amongst amateurs. And very often the goal of these shows was to ascertain who could hold the highest note, or who could embellish their song with endless ghetto/gospel scat melismas. Soon, all that superficial posturing became far more important than the song itself, and songs that were subtle, sophisticated or delicate quickly became out-of-fashion, because they did not elicit wild applause on these “talent” programs. As we know, anyone who can harness the power of the Internet, can grow very rich indeed. Starting in the mid-90’s—- coeval with the rise of the ‘Net—- certain popsong styles became etched in stone. There has been the feeling of, “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it”, and basically no new pop song styles have arisen since the mid-1990’s. If a particular sound and groove sell well, there is no impetus at all to change it or to try new musical ideas. AM and FM radio used to expose a relatively wide spectrum of musical styles to the listener; today, any listener can define a very narrow channel of styles he wants to listen to, and never be exposed to any style outside of that narrow channel. Country-Western music used to be about warmth and sincerity, but with the advent of Autotune technology, it is now as slick, superficial and anodyne as any other flavor of pop. Meanwhile, newer generations are being born who are raised on this new ersatz stuff, and who do not remember when pop music was real, assume that this new falsehood is simply the “new normal”. AM and FM radio used to be the channels by which most people heard new pop music, and because those channels were so relatively narrow and limited, musicians and DJ’s could assert some control, and limit what got heard by the public. With the advent of the ‘Net and other digital media, all music formats have mostly been shattered, and there is an “anything goes” ethos afoot, with musical subgenres proliferating— usually with absurd, pretentious or arbitrary characteristics. In other words, nowadays you have non-music performed by non-musicians in an endless galaxy of audio choices. This all but squelches out the genuine musician who writes and performs his own songs. Cream doesn’t necessarily rise to the top anymore. Another factor in this current malaise… is that sincere at-home and at-school musical instrument learning has been greatly curtailed. Many high schools have discontinued their Music programs. Few young kids want to work hard, and for years, at learning the piano or guitar…. when tricky digital instruments can simulate the sound FOR them. That’s why Rap was born: it was thought that there was no further need for learning Melody, Harmony and Lyric-Writing. One could just shout over a synthetic drumbeat. Before Rap, pop music was most often about finding what was beautiful or singular or impressive about the human experience; after Rap, any subject matter, no matter how vulgar, crude, ephemeral or vicious became the style. Today, the only permissible emotions a popsinger may evince are 1). braggadocious sexual posturing, and 2). aggression/anger. All other emotions are taboo… thought to be wimpy. There are a host of reasons why most modern pop music is crap, but these are a few.
